content: Act as a helpful AI assistant
In Julia, Write a function `keep_only_names` which iterates over the provided list of words (`words`) and removes all words that do not start with a capital letter (eg, remove "dog" but keep "Dog").

Here is an example of how you could write this function in Julia. In Julia, we typically use a comprehension to filter arrays which is more efficient than using traditional loops.

```julia
function keep_only_names(words)
    return [word for word in words if startswith(word, uppercase(first(word))) && word == titlecase(word)]
end
```
This function iterates over each word in the provided list and keeps only those that are capitalized. The `startswith` function is used to check whether a word starts with an uppercase letter. The `uppercase(first(word))` part makes sure we compare the first letter of the word against its uppercase version, because Julia's `startswith` function is case sensitive. Also `titlecase(word)` ensures that only words with title-cased format are kept (for example "Dog" but not "DOG").

You can call this function like so:

```julia
words = ["dog", "Cat", "Mouse", "BIRD", "Fish", "bat", "Hippo"]
print(keep_only_names(words))  # output is ["Cat", "Mouse", "Fish", "Hippo"]
```
This example will keep words that start with a capital letter and are in title case. It does not consider words like "BIRD" or "DOG". If you want to include them, remove the condition `word == titlecase(word)` from function.
